title.narrative: Providing Quality Integrated Primary and Reproductive Healthcare services to conflict affected IDPs in Monguno, Jere and Maiduguri LGA, Borno State

description.narrative:
In response to the influx of Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) into MMC (Maiduguri) and Monguno local government areas (LGA) in Borno state, the IRC responded by providing emergency primary and reproductive healthcare for the affected women, men, girls and boys through direct treatment at IRC facilities. Through this OCHA-supported action, the IRC will further strengthen the provision of health care services by providing primary and reproductive care at existing static health facilities at the Stadium IDP Camp, Bakassi Camp and Teachers Village Camp (TVC) in Maiduguri and in Flatari Camp at Monguno.
As part of an integrated, comprehensive package for direct healthcare service delivery, the IRC will run a reproductive health clinic targeting adolescent girls, women of child bearing age, and pregnant and lactating women (PLW). The IRC will provide clinical management of rape for all identified cases of gender based violence, (GBV) ante-natal services, post-natal services, and syndromic management of sexually transmitted infection (STIs) services.
The project will also address the referral gap by establishing referral pathways and mechanisms, providing logistic support, and paying hospital cost for all IDPs in the targeted camps and host communities who present with acute medical or obstetric emergencies. Referral linkages will be established to secondary health centers and non-health actors, such as the IRC’s Protection team, ensuring associated vulnerabilities of women of reproductive age, pregnant and lactating women, adolescent girls, and children under 5 are reduced further, and allowing all IDPs to receive a holistic package of care that adopts a public health approach.
The IRC will also strengthen community-level mechanisms by using selected and trained community health volunteers to carry out household sensitization sessions, active case findings, and referrals to IRC health facilities. Routine immunization services will be provided and expanded to include mass deworming and vitamin A supplementation to all children under 5.
Through this action the IRC will ensure that the needs of the most vulnerable, including women, men, girls and boys will be protected by conducting trainings to the IRC health program staff and community health volunteers on prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse, child safeguarding and code of conduct and ensuring that protection and gender is mainstreamed into all activities.
